diy_objections.objection: I think I can fix this myself / My friend can do it cheaper

The tricky parts are [SPECIFICS]. We'll warranty our work, which protects you if anything goes wrong. But I respect doing it yourself when it makes sense.
diy_objections.reframe: Respect their capability while highlighting complexity and warranty value

comparison_objections.objection: I got a cheaper quote somewhere else
comparison_objections.wrong_approach: Badmouthing competitors or assuming they're using inferior parts
comparison_objections.authentic_approach: I'm glad you're getting multiple quotes - that's smart. Let's compare what's included. Are they using [OEM/QUALITY PARTS]? What warranty do they offer? comparison_objections.reframe: Compare value and specifics rather than just price

knowledge_objections.objection: I don't understand what you're telling me
knowledge_objections.wrong_approach: Using more technical jargon or showing impatience
knowledge_objections.authentic_approach: Let me explain this in regular terms - I should have done that from the start. [USE ANALOGY]. Does that make sense? What questions do you have? I want you to understand exactly what's happening with your car.
knowledge_objections.reframe: Take responsibility for clear communication and welcome questions

necessity_objections.objection: The car is running fine, why do I need this service?

thread_structure: Your check engine light just came on. Here's what it ACTUALLY means and what to do in the next 24 hours (most people get this wrong) 🧵
First: DON'T PANIC. A solid light vs flashing light means completely different things.
Solid light = Schedule service soon. Flashing light = PULL OVER NOW. Here's why...
Most common causes: 1) Loose gas cap ($0) 2) O2 sensor ($200-300) 3) Catalytic converter ($1000+)
What to do RIGHT NOW: Check your gas cap. Tighten it. Drive for a day. Light still on? Next step...
Get it scanned for FREE at AutoZone/O'Reilly. Write down the code. Don't let them sell you parts yet.
Google the code + your car model. Reddit and forums will tell you if it's serious or can wait.
Pro tip: If you ignore it, you're risking bigger damage AND you'll fail emissions testing.

thread_structure: Buying a used car? Run these 5 checks BEFORE the test drive or you'll regret it. #3 saved me from a $4,000 mistake 🚗
1. VIN check on NICB.org (FREE). Checks if it's stolen or salvage titled. Takes 30 seconds.
2. Carfax/AutoCheck ($40). Worth every penny. Look for: accidents, title issues, service history gaps.
3. Check for frame damage: Look under car for crumpled metal, mismatched paint, welding marks. This is the $4K mistake I avoided.
4. Fluid check: Pull dipstick. Milky oil = head gasket ($2000 fix). Dark transmission fluid = problems.
5. Walk away test: List the car at 2am. If you're not excited, don't buy it. Desperation leads to bad decisions.
Bonus: Bring a mechanic or pay for pre-purchase inspection ($100-150). Cheapest insurance ever.
Never skip these. Even from 'honest' sellers. People lie about cars they're emotionally attached to.

thread_structure: Your car just overheated on the highway. You have 60 seconds to make the right choice or you're looking at a $5,000+ engine replacement. Here's what to do 🚨
Step 1: PULL OVER IMMEDIATELY. Don't try to make it home. Every second = more damage.
Step 2: Turn OFF the engine. Turn ON the heat full blast to pull heat from engine. Yes, even in summer.
Step 3: DO NOT open the radiator cap. Pressurized coolant will explode in your face. Wait 30+ minutes.
Step 4: Call for a tow. Don't restart the engine. "Just checking if it's fixed" = blown head gasket.
Why this happens: Low coolant, failed thermostat, broken water pump, or radiator leak.
What NOT to do: Add cold water to hot engine (will crack), keep driving (warped heads), ignore it (seized engine)
Prevention: Check coolant monthly. Look for leaks. Replace coolant every 50k miles.
